conversations.content: I think I just hit a bone

content.Question_answer:
It's completely normal to encounter bone when inserting the spinal needle, so don't worry too much. Here's what you can do: gently withdraw the needle just a little bit and try redirecting it slightly. Make sure you're keeping the needle aligned towards the patient's belly button. This process can take a few adjustments, so stay patient and confident. You're doing a great job!

To see this step in action, you can watch these clips from the procedure for guidance.

conversations.content: I have already stucked for 5 minutes, ask me some questions to make sure that I am on the right trackNow I'm stuck at step 2

content.Question_answer: Absolutely, let's make sure you're on the right track. In step 2, you're focusing on identifying the anatomical landmarks. Can you describe how you're locating the iliac crests and ensuring you're marking the correct interspace? Remember, your goal is to find that imaginary line between the iliac crests and locate the L4 spinous process. Once you've done that, you should be able to feel the midline and mark it. How's it going with that part? Let me know if you need a bit more guidance!
